title: Funerary inscription for Mousa

support._: A large rectangular slab of the local yellowish limestone. Intact on all sides, with traces of plaster around the outer edges of the front face, suggesting it was mounted in a wall at some point. Uncertain whether it was always a distinct slab, or was sawn out of the rock on discovery, though the former seems more likely. The rear is rough and unfinished. The front face is arranged into three distinct panels, with three distinct inscriptions. The central text is inset in a panel, which is framed by relief carved columns and a tympanum, which are however incomplete: the column on the left is lightly delineated in relief, with the mouldings below the capital detailed, but the capital itself not detailed; the central area of the tympanum is recessed, but the rest of the pediment only marked out by incised lines; the right column is likewise only marked by incised lines, but faint lines tracing a Corinthian capital are visible. The texts to the left and right, are aligned with this via grid lines. Although broadly similar, there are notable stylistic differences between all three texts, suggesting different masons, and potentially separate moments of carving, and for that reason they are here recorded as separate texts. This is the central text. Same support as  and

layout.p: Text over six lines, set in a recessed panel in the style of a temple facade, but without guidelines. Some use of interpuncts and vacats in the text.

handNote.lettering: Text is deeply incised in letters of slightly varying size. Extensive use of serifs, with several letters tending to the cursive. Alpha has straight bar, curving ends; epsilon is lunate with equal length mid-bar; zeta is large and curved; kappa has near full-length arms; mu has slanting strokes that reach the lower line, but often join before the top and have extended upper strokes; pi has overlapping cross bar; rho has closed eye; sigma is lunate. Elegant hedera in line 2; use of vacats in age at death.

provenanceFound._: Purchased by the Siracusa museum on 05.02.1895, said to come from the Grotticelli necropolis / Teracati

provenanceObserved._: Prag 2022-04-28, Magazzino B, Museo Archeologico Regionale Paolo Orsi, Siracusa

museum.name: Museo Archeologico Regionale Paolo Orsi
museum.description: An outstanding collection of archaeological material. The collection ranges from Siracusa and the surrounding territory (Megara Hyblaia, Akrai, Kasmenai etc) to encompass all of eastern Sicily, reaching as far as Gela and Agrigento. The ground floor covers prehistory through to the end of the Classical period. Upstairs includes Hellenistic and Roman Syracuse and a display of material from the catacombs. A gallery displaying material from Hellenistic eastern Sicily is in preparation.

A large rectangular slab of the local yellowish limestone. Intact on all sides, with traces of plaster around the outer edges of the front face, suggesting it was mounted in a wall at some point. Uncertain whether it was always a distinct slab, or was sawn out of the rock on discovery, though the former seems more likely. The rear is rough and unfinished. The front face is arranged into three distinct panels, with three distinct inscriptions. The central text is inset in a panel, which is framed by relief carved columns and a tympanum, which are however incomplete: the column on the left is lightly delineated in relief, with the mouldings below the capital detailed, but the capital itself not detailed; the central area of the tympanum is recessed, but the rest of the pediment only marked out by incised lines; the right column is likewise only marked by incised lines, but faint lines tracing a Corinthian capital are visible. The texts to the left and right, are aligned with this via grid lines. Although broadly similar, there are notable stylistic differences between all three texts, suggesting different masons, and potentially separate moments of carving, and for that reason they are here recorded as separate texts. This is the central text. Same support as ISic001871 and ISic001873

Μοῦσα χρηστὰ ❦ καὶ ἄμεμπτε χαῖρε ἔζη σε μῆνες ι · ἡμέρας κε
Text from autopsy Orsi: ΧΑΙΡΕ · ΕΖΗ lapis: ΜΗΝϹϹ

Mousa, worthy and blameless, farewell! She lived 10 months, 25 days.

The name Mousa is well attested in southern Italy, but rarely in Sicily (at Aitna, Syracusae and Tauromenium). There is no clear basis for determining the potential relationship between Kopria, Mousa and Gamike, except that it seems likely that Mousa was the child of one of the other two. See also ISic001871 and ISic001873.

Orsi 1896 400 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001709
